case_name: Unikat Sankunni Menon v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 274 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 274 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1965 of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Civil Writ Petition No. 336 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1965 of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Civil Writ Petition No. 336 of 1964.

facts.text: The High Court of Rajasthan dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the petition and, consequently, the appellant has come up to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 before the High Court of Rajasthan claiming that words 'without special pay' in 1956 Rules invalid under Articles 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: It was on the basis of these Rules that the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court of Rajasthan claiming that the words without special pay in the Rajasthan Civil Services  Rationalisation of Pay Scales  Rules Schedules, 1956 may be declared as invalid and violative of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant Unikat Sankunni Menon was in the service of the Rajasthan Government in the Secretariat after Rajasthan was constituted as a State.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Bhargava, J. The appellant, Unikat Sankunni Menon, was in the service of the Rajasthan Government in the Secretariat after Rajasthan was companystituted as a State.

facts.text: Rajasthan Secretariat Service Rules, 1954 framed by Rajpramukh under Article 309, brought into force from 10th January, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the Rajasthan Secretariat Service Rules, 1954 were framed by the Rajpramukh under Article 309 of the Constitution of India and were brought into force with effect from 10th January, 1955.

facts.text: Under 1954 Rules, appellant became member of Rajasthan Secretariat Service (R.S.S.) holding post of Assistant Secretary with time-scale Rs. 250-25-400-EB-25-500 and special pay Rs. 75/- per month.

anchor.surface_text: Under these Rules, the appellant became a member of the Rajasthan Secretariat Service  hereinafter referred to as the R.S.S. . He was, at that time, holding the post of an Assistant Secretary which carried the time-scale of Rs. 250-25-400-EB-25-500. He was also drawing a special pay of Rs. 75/- per month.

facts.text: Rajpramukh promulgated Rajasthan Civil Services Rationalisation of Pay Scales Rules and Schedules, 1956 by notification dated 25th May, 1956 under Art. 309.

anchor.surface_text: By the numberification dated 25th May, 1956, the Rajpramukh, again acting under Art. 309 of the Constitution of India, promulgated Rajasthan Civil Services  Rationalisation of Pay Scales  Rules and Schedules, 1956.

facts.text: Under 1956 Rules, Assistant Secretaries posts in ordinary time-scale of R.S.S. grade Rs. 250-25-500-EB-25-750 with special pay Rs. 75/-; Deputy Secretaries selection posts Rs. 500-30-740-EB-30-800-50-900 without special pay.

anchor.surface_text: Under these Rules, the grades of pay applicable to Deputy Secretaries and Assistant Secretaries were revised. The posts of Assistant Secretaries were shown as belonging to the ordinary time-scale of the R.S.S., carrying the grade of Rs. 250-25-500-EB-25-750 with a special pay of Rs. 75/-. Further, it was laid down that there will be selection posts for members of the R.S.S. which were indicated as posts of Deputy Secretaries to Government by putting this designation in brackets, and a new scale of Rs. 500-30-740-EB30-800-50- 900 without special pay was prescribed for these selection posts.

facts.text: Appellant appointed as Deputy Secretary on 10th January, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: These were the Rules in force when, on 10th January, 1959, the appellant was appointed as Deputy Secretary.

facts.text: On appointment date, appellant drawing salary of Rs. 475/- p.m. in ordinary time scale of R.S.S. plus special pay Rs. 75/- as Assistant Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: On that date, he was drawing a salary of Rs. 475/p.m. in the ordinary time scale of the R.S.S. and was also getting a special pay of Rs. 75/- , as he was holding the post of an Assistant Secretary to Government.

facts.text: On appointment as Deputy Secretary, appellant's salary fixed at Rs. 650/- (next higher stage above calculated Rs. 625/- per formula).

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, on his appointment as Deputy Secretary, which was a selection post for the R.S.S., his salary was fixed at Rs. 650/-. Under the formula laid down in the remarks column, mentioned above, the salary admissible to him came to Rs. 625/-, but, since in the new grade fixed for the selection posts there was no stage at Rs. 625/-, his pay was fixed at Rs. 650/- at the next higher stage above the amount calculated in his case on the basis of the formula laid down in the remarks column.

facts.text: Governor of Rajasthan promulgated Rajasthan Civil Services Revised Pay Rules, 1961 under proviso to Art. 309.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the grades for the posts of Dy. Secretaries and Assistant Secretaries were again revised by the Governor of Rajasthan under the proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution by promulgating the Rajasthan Civil Services  Revised Pay  Rules, 1961.

facts.text: Under 1961 Rules, Assistant Secretary R.S.S. grade Rs. 360-25-560-30-590-EB-30-860-900 (merging special pay); Deputy Secretary Rs. 550-30-820-EB-30-850-50-1100.

anchor.surface_text: Under these Rules, the grade applicable to Assistant Secretary to Government belonging to the R.S.S. was prescribed as Rs. 360-25-560-30-590-EB-30-860-900. The Rules also indicated that this revised scale had been prescribed as a result of merging the special pay in the grade pay itself. The grade for Deputy Secretaries to Government was also revised to Rs. 550-30-820-EB-30850-50-1 100.

facts.text: In 1966, latest grade for R.S.S. Deputy Secretaries is Rs. 900-50-1500.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that, subsequently, there was another revision of scales of pay in the year 1966, and the latest grade applicable to the members of the R.S.S. holding the posts of Deputy Secretaries is Rs. 900-50-1500.

facts.text: Members of Rajasthan Administrative Service (R.A.S.) holding Deputy Secretary posts entitled to special pay of Rs. 100/- under 1950 Rules, later Rs. 150/- under subsequent rules.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Rajasthan Civil Services  Unification of Pay Scales  Rules and Schedules, 1950, which were in force until the year 1956, a member of the R.A.S., on appointment as Deputy Secretary, drew salary in the same grade of Rs. 500- 25-700 with a special pay of Rs. 100/- in the same way as a member of the R.S.S.

facts.text: Under 1956 Rules, R.A.S. members on Deputy Secretary posts get special pay Rs. 150/- in addition to their time scale or selection grade.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules prescribed a special pay of Rs. 1501- for the members of the R.A.S. when appointed to posts of Deputy Secretaries to Government.

facts.text: R.S.S. and R.A.S. are distinct services with different recruitment, qualifications, grades, and posts.

anchor.surface_text: The first is that the appellant comes to the post of a Deputy Secretary from the R.S.S., which is a service distinct and separate from the R.A.S. The methods of recruitment, qualifications, etc., of the two Services are not identical.

facts.text: Members of R.S.S. employed only in Secretariat; R.A.S. mostly outside but some in Secretariat.

anchor.surface_text: The members of the R.S.S. are meant to be employed in the Secretariat only, while members of the R.A.S. are mostly meant for posts which are outside the Secretariat though some posts in the Secretariat can be filled by members of the R.A.S.

facts.text: Court holds no discrimination under Art. 14 or 16 as RSS and RAS members not entitled to identical pay for same post due to different services.

anchor.surface_text: No such equality is required either by Art. 14 or Art. 16 of the Constitution.

facts.text: R.S.S. Deputy Secretaries get special higher grade; R.A.S. continue their scale plus special pay Rs. 150/-, not higher grade.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, under the latest Rules, a member of the R.S.S., on appointment as Deputy Secretary, draws salary in the grade of Rs. 900-50-1500. On the other hand, a member of the R.A.S., appointed as Deputy Secretary, is not granted pay in this scale.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal has no force and is dismissed, but, in the circumstances of this case, we make no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, learned counsel for the appellant drew our attention to Rule 7 3 1  of the Rajasthan Civil Service Rules, 1951, framed under Article 309 of the Constitution, defining special pay. The definition given in the Rule is that Special Pay means an addition of the nature of pay, to the emoluments of a post or of a government servant, granted in consideration of -  a  the specially arduous nature of the duties,  b  a specific addition to the work or responsibility or  c  the unhealthiness of the locality in which the work is performed.

concepts.interpretation: Special pay is an addition to emoluments for arduous duties etc., compared to previous or ordinary posts, not inherent to the post itself.

issues.text: Whether the words 'without special pay' in the Rajasthan Civil Services Rationalisation of Pay Scales Rules Schedules, 1956 may be declared as invalid and violative of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It was on the basis of these Rules that the appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court of Rajasthan claiming that the words without special pay in the Rajasthan Civil Services  Rationalisation of Pay Scales  Rules Schedules, 1956 may be declared as invalid and violative of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the Rules applicable from time to time to members of the R.S.S. on appointment to the posts of Deputy Secretaries were at no stage made less favourable than the Rules previously applicable or prejudiced vested rights

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the appellant has to be examined in two different aspects,. The first aspect is that the Rules, as applicable from time to time to members of the R.S.S. on appointment to the posts of Deputy Secretaries, were, at no stage, made less favourable than the Rules previously applicable.

issues.text: Whether denial of special pay to members of R.S.S. appointed as Deputy Secretaries while admissible to members of R.A.S. holding similar posts violates Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The second aspect, and the one on which reliance was mainly placed by learned counsel for the appellant in this appeal, is that the Rules, on the face of them, show that, in the case of members of the R.S.S. appointed as Deputy Secretaries, no special pay is admissible, while special pay is admissible to members of the R.A.S. when holding similar posts.

issues.text: Whether the Rajpramukh or the Governor was incompetent to promulgate the revised Rules under Article 309 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Further, it was, at no stage, urged that the Rajpramukh or the Governor was incompetent to promulgate these revised Rules from time to time in exercise of his power under Article 309 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether Article 14 requires equal pay for equal work between members of different services

anchor.surface_text: The abstract doctrine of equal pay for equal work has nothing to do with Art. 14. The contention that Art. 14 of the Constitution has been violated, therefore, fails.

issues.text: Whether the definition of special pay under Rule 731 requires granting special pay to R.S.S. members as Deputy Secretaries when granted to R.A.S.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, learned counsel for the appellant drew our attention to Rule 731 of the Rajasthan Civil Service Rules, 1951, framed under Article 309 of the Constitution, defining special pay.

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the appellant has to be examined in two different aspects,. The first aspect is that the Rules, as applicable from time to time to members of the R.S.S. on appointment to the posts of Deputy Secretaries, were, at no stage, made less favourable than the Rules previously applicable.

arguments.claim: Rules discriminate by denying special pay to RSS members appointed as Deputy Secretaries while granting it to RAS members holding similar posts, violating Articles 14 and 16

anchor.surface_text: The second aspect, and the one on which reliance was mainly placed by learned counsel for the appellant in this appeal, is that the Rules, on the face of them, show that, in the case of members of the R.S.S. appointed as Deputy Secretaries, no special pay is admissible, while special pay is admissible to members of the R.A.S. when holding similar posts.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Rules, on the face of them, show that, in the case of members of the R.S.S. appointed as Deputy Secretaries, numberspecial pay is admissible, while sp

arguments.court_reasoning: RSS and RAS are separate services with different recruitment, qualifications, duties, and pay grades; equality not required between different classes

arguments.claim: RSS and RAS are distinct services with different recruitment, qualifications, grades, and posts, justifying different pay treatment including special pay

anchor.surface_text: There are two reasons why this grievance put forward on behalf of the appellant has to be rejected. The first is that the appellant comes to the post of a Deputy Secretary from the R.S.S., which is a service distinct and separate from the R.A.S. The methods of recruitment, qualifications, etc., of the two Services are not identical.

arguments.claim: Precedent in All India Station Masters case holds equality of opportunity under Art 16 applies only within same class of employees, not between separate classes

anchor.surface_text: This principle was explained by this Court first in the case of All India Station Masters and Assistant Station Masters Association Others v. General Manager, Central Railways and Others 1 . In that case, the question arose about the rights of promotion of Assistant Station Masters and Guards already employed in the Railway Service.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Kishori Mohanlal Bakshi case confirms no violation of Art 14 in different pay scales for different classes doing same work

anchor.surface_text: The same principle was later confirmed in the case of Kishori Mohanlal Bakshi v. Union of India 2 . In that case, persons appointed to Class II of Income-tax Officers claimed that there was discrimination against them in the matter of pay-scales, as compared with Income-tax Officers recruited direct to the Class I Service.

arguments.claim: RSS members receive special higher pay grade for Deputy Secretary posts while RAS members continue in their own lower scale plus special pay, so no discrimination

anchor.surface_text: Thus, under the latest Rules, a member of the R.S.S., on appointment as Deputy Secretary, draws salary in the grade of Rs. 900-50-1500. On the other hand, a member of the R.A.S., appointed as Deputy Secretary, is not granted pay in this scale.

arguments.claim: Per Rule 731 definition of special pay, post of Deputy Secretary involves arduous duties equally for RSS and RAS members, so special pay required for RSS too

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, learned counsel for the appellant drew our attention to Rule 731 of the Rajasthan Civil Service Rules, 1951, framed under Article 309 of the Constitution, defining special pay. The definition given in the Rule is that Special Pay means an addition of the nature of pay, to the emoluments of a post or of a government servant,

arguments.court_reasoning: Misconception of rule scope; special pay is relative to prior post or ordinary service duties, not inherent to post; RSS gets higher selection grade instead

arguments.claim: Abstract doctrine of equal pay for equal work unrelated to Art 14

anchor.surface_text: The abstract doctrine of equal pay for equal work has nothing to do with Art. 14. The contention that Art. 14 of the Constitution has been violated, therefore, fails.

arguments.claim: Rajpramukh and Governor competent to promulgate revised pay rules under Art 309; no challenge raised

anchor.surface_text: Further, it was, at no stage, urged that the Rajpramukh or the Governor was incompetent to promulgate these revised Rules from time to time in exercise of his power under Article 309 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The Rules applicable from time to time to members of the R.S.S. on appointment to the posts of Deputy Secretaries were, at no stage, made less favourable than the Rules previously applicable or prejudiced vested rights of members of the R.S.S.

anchor.surface_text: Further, it was, at no stage, urged that the Rajpramukh or the Governor was incompetent to promulgate these revised Rules from time to time in exercise of his power under Article 309 of the Constitution. The Rules thus applicable to the member of the R.S.S. on appointment to the post of Deputy Secretary, against which the appellant made his grievance in the High Court, cannot be held to be vitiated in any manner, if considered by themselves in the light of rights which the members of the R.S.S. possessed from time to time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Successive rules ensured minimum pay increase, higher scales than previous, no reduction in emoluments compared to prior rules, no prejudice to vested rights under Art 309.

holdings.text: No equality of pay or special pay is required under Articles 14 or 16 between members of distinct services (R.S.S. and R.A.S.) holding the same post (Deputy Secretary).

anchor.surface_text: The second aspect, and the one on which reliance was mainly placed by learned counsel for the appellant in this appeal, is that the Rules, on the face of them, show that, in the case of members of the R.S.S. appointed as Deputy Secretaries, no special pay is admissible, while special pay is admissible to members of the R.A.S. when holding similar posts. ... No such equality is required either by Art. 14 or Art. 16 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: R.S.S. and R.A.S. have different recruitment, qualifications, duties, grades; equality under Art 14/16 applies within same class, not between separate independent classes/services.

holdings.text: Articles 14 and 16 do not require identical emoluments disregarding source service or recruitment method for appointments to the same post.

anchor.surface_text: No such equality is required either by Art. 14 or Art. 16 of the Constitution. This principle was explained by this Court first in the case of All India Station Masters and Assistant Station Masters Association Others v. General Manager, Central Railways and Others 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from All India Station Masters' Association: equality of opportunity only between members of same class of employees, not different classes.

holdings.text: The abstract doctrine of equal pay for equal work has nothing to do with Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The abstract doctrine of equal pay for equal work has nothing to do with Art. 14. The contention that Art. 14 of the Constitution has been violated, therefore, fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmed by precedent in Kishori Mohanlal Bakshi v. Union of India: different pay scales for different classes doing same work do not violate Art 14.

holdings.text: Rule 731 defining special pay does not require granting special pay to R.S.S. members as Deputy Secretaries merely because granted to R.A.S. members; special pay is relative to prior/ordinary duties, not inherent to post.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that this submission is made on a misconception of the scope of this Rule. The Rule, in defining special pay, envisages an addition of the nature of pay to the emoluments of either a post or of a government servant and, consequently, it is clear that a special pay is to be granted, if a person is appointed to a post which is specially arduous in nature as compared with the earlier post held by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special pay granted relative to previous post or ordinary service duties; R.S.S. gets higher selection grade instead for promotion from Assistant Secretary.

holdings.text: No discrimination under Art. 14 or denial of equality under Art. 16; R.S.S. members get special higher grade for Deputy Secretary posts, while R.A.S. get special pay added to their lower scale.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, under the latest Rules, a member of the R.S.S., on appointment as Deputy Secretary, draws salary in the grade of Rs. 900-50-1500. On the other hand, a member of the R.A.S., appointed as Deputy Secretary, is not granted pay in this scale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different fixation methods: higher grade for R.S.S. vs. own scale + special pay for R.A.S.; overall no less favorable.

precedents.citation: All India Station Masters and Assistant Station Masters Association Others v. General Manager, Central Railways and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: All India Station Masters and Assistant Station Masters Association Others v. General Manager, Central Railways and Others 1 . In that case, the question arose about the rights of promotion of Assistant Station Masters and Guards already employed in the Railway Service.

precedents.case_name: All India Station Masters and Assistant Station Masters Association v. General Manager, Central Railways
precedents.cited_proposition: Equality of opportunity under Article 16 applies only between members of the same class of employees and not between members of separate, independent classes
precedents.cited_holding: equality of opportunity in matters of promotion, must mean equality as between members of the same class of employees, and not equality between members of separate, independent classes

precedents.citation: Kishori Mohanlal Bakshi v. Union of India 2

anchor.surface_text: Kishori Mohanlal Bakshi v. Union of India 2 . In that case, persons appointed to Class II of Income-tax Officers claimed that there was discrimination against them in the matter of pay-scales, as compared with Income-tax Officers recruited direct to the Class I Service.

precedents.case_name: Kishori Mohanlal Bakshi v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Different pay scales for Class I and Class II officers doing the same work does not violate Article 14; abstract doctrine of equal pay for equal work has nothing to do with Article 14
precedents.cited_holding: The abstract doctrine of equal pay for equal work has nothing to do with Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: Further, it was, at no stage, urged that the Rajpramukh or the Governor was incompetent to promulgate these revised Rules from time to time in exercise of his power under Article 309 of the Constitution. The Rules thus applicable to the member of the R.S.S. on appointment to the post of Deputy Secretary, against which the appellant made his grievance in the High Court, cannot be held to be vitiated in any manner, if considered by themselves in the light of rights which the members of the R.S.S. possessed from time to time.
The appeal has numberforce and is dismissed, but, in the circumstances of this case, we make numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: The second aspect, and the one on which reliance was mainly placed by learned counsel for the appellant in this appeal, is that the Rules, on the face of them, show that, in the case of members of the R.S.S. appointed as Deputy Secretaries, no special pay is admissible, while special pay is admissible to members of the R.A.S. when holding similar posts. ... No such equality is required either by Art. 14 or Art. 16 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The abstract doctrine of equal pay for equal work has nothing to do with Art. 14. The contention that Art. 14 of the Constitution has been violated, therefore, fails.

It appears to us that this submission is made on a misconception of the scope of this Rule. The Rule, in defining special pay, envisages an addition of the nature of pay to the emoluments of either a post or of a government servant and, consequently, it is clear that a special pay is to be granted, if a person is appointed to a post which is specially arduous in nature as compared with the earlier post held by him.
The appeal has numberforce and is dismissed, but, in the circumstances of this case, we make numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, under the latest Rules, a member of the R.S.S., on appointment as Deputy Secretary, draws salary in the grade of Rs. 900-50-1500. On the other hand, a member of the R.A.S., appointed as Deputy Secretary, is not granted pay in this scale.
The appeal has numberforce and is dismissed, but, in the circumstances of this case, we make numberorder as to companyts.
